Muscle imbalances disrupt the normal biomechanics of the joint or joints they surround. Stabilizing muscles (called stabilizers) maintain excellent posture and optimal biomechanics by ensuring congruence of the joint surfaces but when the stabilizers weaken from injury, poor posture or extended periods of sitting, other muscles attempt to substitute or compensate for this weakness.

These compensatory muscles are named mobilizers since they are accountable for leading to movement and provide little in the way of stabilizing the body. Mobilizing muscles cannot perform the function of the two stabilizing and mobilizing, and as a result change the typical movement of the joint or body part.

These compensations and substitutions outcome in a wasting of muscle energy and electrical power and abnormal joint put on, ultimately leading to injury. Widespread locations of compensation, injury and pain for golfers are the low back and shoulders.

The muscles of prime importance are the transversus abdominis and the multifidus (deepest abdominal and back muscle respectively).

The core muscles manage and stabilize the region of the physique where the center of gravity is situated and in which all human movement, such as the golf swing begins. The core acts as the main anchor for virtually every single muscle in the physique to "pull off" and as the bridge for conducting forces amongst the upper and decrease physique. The powerful leg muscles attach to the LPHC straight by way of the hip, even though the muscles of the arms and shoulders attach indirectly by means of the spine and trunk.
